fluoromind.cpca package

Submodules

fluoromind.cpca.CPCA module

Complex Principal Component Analysis (CPCA).

A dimensionality reduction technique that extends traditional PCA to complex-valued data. It can be used to analyze phase-amplitude relationships in time series data.

param n_components:

Number of components to keep. If None, keeps all components.

type n_components:

int, optional

param force_complex:

If True, converts real-valued input to complex using Hilbert transform.

type force_complex:

bool, default=True

param standardize:

If True, standardizes the input data using z-score normalization.

type standardize:

bool, default=True

param **solver_args:

Additional arguments to pass to scipy.sparse.linalg.svds.

type **solver_args:

dict

fluoromind.cpca.CPCA.components_

Principal components (eigenvectors).

Type:

ndarray

fluoromind.cpca.CPCA.scores_

Projection of the data onto the principal components.

Type:

ndarray

fluoromind.cpca.CPCA.singular_values_

The singular values corresponding to each component.

Type:

ndarray

fluoromind.cpca.CPCA.explained_variance_

The amount of variance explained by each component.

Type:

ndarray

fluoromind.cpca.CPCA.explained_variance_ratio_

The percentage of variance explained by each component.

Type:

ndarray

Module contents

Complex Principal Component Analysis (CPCA) for Neuroimaging Data Analysis

This module implements Complex Principal Component Analysis, a variant of PCA that can handle complex-valued data, particularly useful for neuroimaging analysis.

class fluoromind.cpca.CPCA(n_components: int | None = None, force_complex: bool = True, standardize: bool = True, **solver_args)[source]

Bases: object

Complex Principal Component Analysis (CPCA).

A dimensionality reduction technique that extends traditional PCA to complex-valued data. It can be used to analyze phase-amplitude relationships in time series data.

Parameters:

  • n_components (int, optional) – Number of components to keep. If None, keeps all components.

  • force_complex (bool, default=True) – If True, converts real-valued input to complex using Hilbert transform.

  • standardize (bool, default=True) – If True, standardizes the input data using z-score normalization.

  • **solver_args (dict) – Additional arguments to pass to scipy.sparse.linalg.svds.

components_

Principal components (eigenvectors).

Type:

ndarray

scores_

Projection of the data onto the principal components.

Type:

ndarray

singular_values_

The singular values corresponding to each component.

Type:

ndarray

explained_variance_

The amount of variance explained by each component.

Type:

ndarray

explained_variance_ratio_

The percentage of variance explained by each component.

Type:

ndarray

Initialize CPCA.

fit(X: ndarray) → CPCA[source]

Fit CPCA model to complex-valued data.

Parameters:

X (ndarray of shape (n_samples, n_features)) – Training data, where n_samples is the number of samples and n_features is the number of features.

Returns:

self – Returns the instance itself.

Return type:

CPCA

inverse_transform(X_transformed: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Transform data back to original space.

Parameters:

X_transformed (ndarray of shape (n_samples, n_components)) – Data in transformed space.

Returns:

Data in original space.

Return type:

ndarray of shape (n_samples, n_features)

Raises:

ValueError – If the model has not been fitted yet.

spatiotemporal_patterns(i: int) → ndarray[source]

Get the spatial patterns of the i-th component.

Parameters:

i (int) – Index of the component.

Returns:

Spatiotemporal patterns for the specified component.

Return type:

ndarray

Raises:

ValueError – If the model has not been fitted yet or if i is out of bounds.

transform(X: ndarray) → ndarray[source]

Transform data into the complex principal component space.

Parameters:

X (ndarray of shape (n_samples, n_features)) – Data to transform.

Returns:

Transformed data in the principal component space.

Return type:

ndarray of shape (n_samples, n_components)

Raises:

ValueError – If the model has not been fitted yet.

fluoromind.cpca.cpca(data: ndarray, n_components: int | None, **kwargs) → CPCA[source]

Convenience function to perform CPCA.

Parameters:

  • data (ndarray) – Input data array.

  • n_components (int, optional) – Number of components to keep.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments to pass to CPCA.

Returns:

Fitted CPCA model.

Return type:

CPCA

fluoromind.cpca.group_cpca(data: List[ndarray], n_components: int | None, **kwargs) → Tuple[ndarray, CPCA][source]

Group multiple datasets and perform CPCA.

Parameters:

  • data (list of ndarray) – List of input data arrays to be grouped.

  • n_components (int, optional) – Number of components to keep.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments to pass to CPCA.

Returns:

A tuple containing: - grouped_data : ndarray

The concatenated and z-scored input data

  • modelCPCA

    The fitted CPCA model

Return type:

tuple
